original: Another week just flew by me. I drove by the new house yesterday and the front window was covered in boxes. We may get the keys at closing, i am getting so excited. If all goes well this week, we will be set for closing a week from wednesday. I was up until after 3:00am last night watching movies with bethany. There has been a lot of movie watching going on around here lately. Here's my rundown; last night we watched thirteen, a movie every mother of a teen should see. It was better then i expected. Then we watched gigli, yeah it was just as bad as the media said it was, but we had to see for ourselves.
polished: Another week flew by. I drove past the new house yesterday, and the front window was covered in boxes. We might receive the keys at closing, which is exciting. If everything goes well this week, we will be set for closing a week from Wednesday. I was up until after 3:00 a.m. last night watching movies with Bethany. There's been a lot of movie-watching going on around here lately. Here's my rundown: last night we watched "Thirteen," a movie every mother of a teen should see. It was better than I expected. Then we watched "Gigli," and it was just as bad as the media said, but we had to see for ourselves.

original: Summer tv tv in the summer used to be a dead zone full of repeats or something. But now there are two great new shows on tv and i have been watching both religiously for the last week. Blow out the gayest concept ever that seemingly has zero gay people in sight. Hairstylist jonothan antin wants build a second location to his incredibly popular west hollywood salon but this time in beverly hills. Normally no one would care, certainly not i, but as i was flipping thru the channels i caught a glipse of jonothan, equally narcissistic and dull looking at a empty space on rodeo dr speak (in a public voice) 'i am going to build here the greatest salon in the history of the world ever!' and i was hooked. Not since rocco have i found such a moron compelling tv watching.
polished: Summer television used to be a dead zone filled with reruns, but now there are two great new shows that I have been watching religiously for the past week. One of them is "Blow Out," which astonishingly lacks any gay presence despite its flamboyant concept. In this show, hairstylist Jonathan Antin aims to expand his immensely popular West Hollywood salon by opening a second location in Beverly Hills. Normally, I wouldn't care, but as I was channel surfing, I glimpsed Jonathan, with his intriguing blend of narcissism and dullness, surveying an empty space on Rodeo Drive. He declared, "I am going to build here the greatest salon in the history of the world!" Instantly, I was captivated. Not since Rocco have I found someone so compelling to watch on TV.

original: What a week ... My right shoulder has tendonitus. It's right under my shoulder blade. So, when i move my arm too much, mainly with a mouse on a computer .... It kills me. I can't move it much now because i was on a spree updating my website and working on other online things. I can barely get up strength to draw anything. Lack of sleep adds to my pain. I'm not too happy right now, but i'll get better. My mom's surgery went ok. Her eyesight has come back some. She can see fuzzy shapes and make out colors. Other than that she's still blind as all sin. Hopefully she'll fully regain her vision soon.
polished: What a week... My right shoulder has tendinitis, right under my shoulder blade. When I move my arm too much, especially using a computer mouse, it causes a lot of pain. I can't move it much now because I was updating my website and working on other online tasks. I can barely muster the strength to draw anything. Lack of sleep worsens my pain. I'm not too happy right now, but I'll get better. My mom's surgery went okay. Some of her eyesight has returned, and she can now see fuzzy shapes and distinguish colors. Other than that, she's still quite blind. Hopefully, she'll fully regain her vision soon.

original: Kindness of strangers... Attempted laundry today with the kids in tow and realized how very quickly the simplest things can become a freaking ordeal. I also learned how remarkably sweet total strangers can be for no reason other than because they feel like being sweet. Trust me. It wasn't like they were trying to get into my pants or anything. I had kid drool all over me and was wearing my 'wash-day' outfit... Also, i'm not surper sure i'll ever be bathing again so it's not like there was even an olefactory incentive there! i am doing two things right now. I am composing an post and i am also watching the collected no doubt videos. I am doing both of these things sitting at my desk in my room.
polished: Attempted laundry today with the kids in tow and quickly realized how the simplest tasks can become quite an ordeal. Remarkably, I discovered how sweet total strangers can be, just because they feel like it. Trust me, it wasn't because they were trying for anything more; I had kid drool on me and was wearing my 'wash-day' outfit. Plus, I'm pretty sure I won't be bathing for a while, so there wasn't even an olfactory incentive! Currently, I'm doing two things: composing a post and watching the collected No Doubt videos, both while sitting at my desk in my room.

original: So it is 11:14pm mst, and here i sit in my bedroom fixing the personal computer of the personnel director from my job. Not that i mind doing it, but i wonder sometimes at how often i find myself fixing someone else's computer as a favour. I'm glad to be able to love and minister to people this way, but where is the line drawn where it comes to the point that you are being taken advantage of? the last couple of weeks, i've been staying up late reading and such, so i was looking forward to hitting the sack early, until i realized it would be more prudent to get this computer out of my bedroom and back into its owner's hands. *laugh* no rest for the weary, right? so i found myself watching joe schmo 2 again tonight.
polished: It's 11:14 PM MST, and I'm sitting in my bedroom repairing the personal computer of my job's personnel director. I don't mind doing it, but I sometimes wonder how often I end up fixing someone else's computer as a favor. I'm happy to help people this way, but where do you draw the line to avoid being taken advantage of? In the past couple of weeks, I've stayed up late reading and such, so I was looking forward to going to bed early—until I realized it would be more prudent to return this computer to its owner. *laugh* No rest for the weary, right? So, I found myself watching Joe Schmo 2 again tonight.

original: Remind me, what did i write about before this? or, a continuation in the 'is this a date?' saga so, after the weird lunch, my confidence shook, i forgot to tell you guys an important piece of the story. Before pat shows up to lunch, dustin starts talking about what a nice guy pat is and how he's trying to find a girlfriend for him. I'm listening and nodding and realizing that we're talking more about finding dustin's best friend a girl, than discussing whatever it is you discuss with a stranger over pink lemonade. I excused myself to the bathroom, looked in the mirror and then silently asked myself: am i being pawned off to the other guy? is this what happens now?
polished: Remind me, what did I write about before this? Or, a continuation in the "is this a date?" saga. After the weird lunch, my confidence was shaken, and I realized I forgot to share an important part of the story. Before Pat showed up for lunch, Dustin started talking about what a nice guy Pat is and how he’s trying to find a girlfriend for him. I was listening, nodding, and realizing that we were talking more about finding Dustin’s best friend a girl than discussing whatever you discuss with a stranger over pink lemonade. I excused myself to the bathroom, looked in the mirror, and silently asked myself: Am I being pawned off to the other guy? Is this what happens now?

original: I would like everyone to think before they act. Actually.. I'd like each and every single person in the world to think before they get out of bed in the morning, and make a commitment to keep thinking all day, and if they're not prepared to, i'd like very much that they'd hop the fuck back in bed, and drift off to an eternal slumber. I'm sick to death of stupid people. No i'm not the smartest motherfucker in the world... But i'm not talking about things that take a lot of brain power, so i think its fair to persecute the inanely stupid. Lets see if i can keep this particular rant to a few particular types, and we'll save some for another day, sound good? great.
polished: I would like everyone to think before they act. Specifically, I'd like each person in the world to think before they get out of bed in the morning and commit to thoughtful behavior all day. If someone isn't prepared to do so, I wish they'd just stay in bed. I'm really tired of dealing with foolishness. I'm not claiming to be the smartest person around, but I'm not talking about anything that requires a lot of intelligence, so I think it's fair to criticize the exceptionally thoughtless. Let's see if I can keep this rant focused on a few specific types, and we can save the rest for another day. Sound good? Great.

original: Two problems with the scenario outlined in my previous post: 1. True, bush is stimulating the economy, but in the wrong way. Urllink robert rubin told npr's marketplace today that bush could have achieved the same stimulus effect without the long term debt hangover by enacting different tax cuts, temporary tax cuts that would benefit low and middle income persons. Ah, robert rubin. The sound of his name is music to our ears. Quick: name one bush administration cabinet official on the domestic side with rubin's gravitas. Still thinking? it'll come to you... 2. We can't give the republicans control only in wartime because they've ingeniously concocted an endless, global 'war on terrorism.'
polished: Two problems with the scenario outlined in my previous post: 1. Bush is indeed stimulating the economy, but in an ineffective manner. Robert Rubin, speaking to NPR's Marketplace, mentioned that Bush could have achieved similar stimulus effects without the burden of long-term debt by enacting different, temporary tax cuts that would aid low- and middle-income individuals. Ah, Robert Rubin—the mere mention of his name delights us. Quick: can you name a Bush administration cabinet official on the domestic side who has Rubin's gravitas? Still thinking? It’ll come to you... 2. We can't entrust Republicans with control only in wartime, as they've cleverly invented an endless global 'war on terrorism.'

original: 'she's saying i'm on the run, i'm chasing guys for fun' ~the offspring umm haven't updated in awhile but not much to say.. Went to the cove to see supernothing, they were good as usual, got to chill with tiago :-).. Sat. Went to work and then out w/ joe and rach, met up with steve, tiago and tom.. polished: Haven't updated in a while, but not much to say. Went to the cove to see Supernothing; they were good as usual. Got to chill with Tiago. On Saturday, went to work and then out with Joe and Rach; met up with Steve, Tiago, and Tom. Came home at about 11:45 and woke up the next morning at 6:45 for a meet. original: Do you ever have one of those moments when you begin to reflect on life? like you're sitting in math class bored out of your skull, and you wonder what exactly goes on in your brain that makes you understand math? and you realize that you exist and you are in math class and you wonder why. Then you realize how amazing existing is. And suddenly it hits you-the fact that you are going off on this random train of thought is incredibly pathetic. Ever had that happen? i hate that. You know what else i hate? block schedules. Who would ever come up with that idea? anyone can see that sitting through a two and a half hour class in any subject is cruel and unusual punishment.
polished: Have you ever had one of those moments when you start reflecting on life? Like you're in math class, bored out of your mind, and you wonder how your brain comprehends math? Then you realize you're in math class and question why. Suddenly, you recognize how incredible existing is. Yet it hits you—going off on this random train of thought feels incredibly aimless. Has that happened to you? I can't stand it. You know what else bothers me? Block schedules. Who thought of that idea? Clearly, enduring a two-and-a-half-hour class in any subject is borderline cruel and unusual punishment.

original: I think that monpoly has run it's course in my life and i vow to never lay my hands on that damn iron (not a hot one but the piece in the game) again. Tonight andy beat me by a few small dollars and won the farquin game, or maybe i let him win on account of him leaving in a few short hours and me wanting him to feel good on his last night here. Well how ever the story goes it can't compare to this texas sized headache i have at the moment, i've taken some aleve and i must say that they are doing the trick, all i need now is some well deserved r&r your telephone's the one that helped me wrap the cord around your neck... At the drive in
polished: I think that Monopoly has run its course in my life, and I vow never to lay my hands on that darn iron (not a hot one, but the piece in the game) again. Tonight, Andy beat me by a few small dollars and won the game—or maybe I let him win because he's leaving in a few hours, and I wanted him to feel good on his last night here. However the story goes, it can't compare to this Texas-sized headache I have at the moment. I've taken some Aleve, and I must say they're doing the trick. All I need now is some well-deserved rest and relaxation.

original: Well... Today's been a long day. We had to drive home from indiana. I guess i'm gonna sort of have to be choosy what i write about because i could really take up a lot of time and space and i just don't have enough energy. First off i have to say that camp was awesome and even better than i could have expected. God's been doing so much stuff in my life lately and it's just awesome. I've sort of turned over a new leaf i guess, but anyway's back to the beginning. We arrived at the twiggs' house on friday evening and we stayed until we left for camp on monday. Most of what we did was go to the fair, church, a parade, walmart and watched movies.
polished: Today's been a long day; we drove home from Indiana. I'll need to be selective about what I write since I could easily go on for quite some time, and I don’t have enough energy. First of all, I must say that camp was incredible, even better than I had anticipated. God has been working in my life lately, and it's amazing. I feel like I've turned over a new leaf. Back to the beginning, we arrived at the Twiggs' house on Friday evening and stayed until we left for camp on Monday. We went to the fair, church, a parade, Walmart, and watched movies.

original: Today is my last day of summer vacation! waaaaaa! and i have a dentist appointment at 9. I hate that, but i'd rather get it over with than try to schedule it during the first month of my surgery rotation. I'm definitely nervous, scared, jittery, and any other words you can think up for 'hell's no, me's don wanna go' to school. This is going to be a whole new ball game for me. As a perfectionist, i love excelling at everything i do. But starting new things is a bitch. I hate being a pawn (like i told cassie: 'i'm going to be the only pawn on the chessboard who insists on moving like a knight'), and i hate not knowing what's going on.
polished: Today is the last day of my summer vacation, and I have a dentist appointment at 9. I hate that, but I'd rather get it over with than try to schedule it during the first month of my surgery rotation. I'm definitely nervous, scared, jittery, and any other words you can think of for not wanting to go back to school. This is going to be a whole new experience for me. As a perfectionist, I love excelling at everything I do, but starting new things is challenging. I hate being a pawn (like I told Cassie: 'I'm going to be the only pawn on the chessboard who insists on moving like a knight'), and I hate not knowing what's going on.

original: Arun shourie talks about how, the present governor of uttar pradesh had warned, as far back as 1996, about the impending threat of the rise of a urllink ' third islamic state ' in the subcontinent . T v rajeswar, the former head of the intelligence bureau and the present governor of uttar pradesh had predicted this dire threat in a series of articles published in the hindustan times, way back in 1996. Shourie raises a valid point when he says, does the fact that you now know that he, and not i, to say nothing of mr advani, wrote all that make the warnings ring true? or do you conclude that because he wrote in this refrain, t v rajeswar is a closet communalist and should not be allowed to continue as governor of uttar pradesh?
polished: Arun Shourie discusses how the current Governor of Uttar Pradesh had forewarned, as early as 1996, about the looming threat of a "third Islamic state" emerging in the subcontinent. T.V. Rajeswar, the former head of the Intelligence Bureau and the present Governor of Uttar Pradesh, had forecasted this serious concern in a series of articles published in the Hindustan Times in 1996. Shourie raises a pertinent question when he asks, does discovering that Rajeswar, rather than himself or Mr. Advani, authored these warnings make them more credible? Or do you conclude that because Rajeswar sounded this alarm, he is a closet communalist who should not continue as Governor of Uttar Pradesh?

original: Attitude: bored mood: indifferent, looking forward to tonight been a long hard day in the trenches here today folks, almost no time to write anything for you readers. However it's good to see tigger(now akcron) taking up the reigns herself and making an appearance and talking about things :) not much to say about things, yesterday was shakespeare on the green, was a lovely play, but i had to leave before closing curtain, which kinda sucked, hopefully someday i'll see the entirety of a shakespeare play. But i digress. polished: Attitude: Bored; Mood: Indifferent. Looking forward to tonight—it's been a long, hard day in the trenches here, folks. Almost no time to write anything for you readers. However, it's good to see Tigger (now Akcron) taking up the reins herself, making an appearance, and discussing things. Not much to say about yesterday; it was Shakespeare on the Green—a lovely play. Unfortunately, I had to leave before the final curtain, which was disappointing. Hopefully, someday I'll see an entire Shakespeare play. But I digress. Akcron is right about the shower problems; it’s frustrating. The humor, though, in seeing someone struggling can be surprisingly entertaining.

original: All of a sudden, for the past two days, i have been overcome with terrible bouts of exhaustion. Bone dead exhaustion. Last evening, i went home, and just slept off, and only got up when my mother called me around eight thirty. And when i woke up, it was all dark, and i hadn't switched the lights on, so i could not figure out what time or date it was, for a few seconds, it was just my mother's voice in the darkness and me grappling with reality. Wonder why i'm feeling so drained... Nice weather this morning. It was drizzling when i came. Although in calcutta i hear it's been raining for the past three days.
polished: Suddenly, over the past two days, I've been overwhelmed with intense exhaustion—utterly bone-tired. Last evening, I went home and immediately fell asleep, only waking when my mother called around eight-thirty. Upon waking, it was completely dark; I hadn't turned on the lights, so I couldn't tell the time or date for a few seconds. It was just my mother's voice in the darkness and me grappling with reality. I wonder why I'm feeling so drained. The weather is pleasant this morning; it was drizzling when I arrived. However, I've heard it’s been raining in Calcutta for the last three days.

original: Last night was the worst. I threw away the sweater i was knitting. I only had about 14 inches. I lost probably $10 worth of yarn (it's $8 a skein). But it had too many stitches by the time i got to the arm holes and the mohair was knotting itself together as i knitted, so frogging (ripping out rows) didn't work well. The yarn broke a lot. I didn't even swear, which is unusual for me. I just morosely ripped and listened to season two of sex and the city (way to go, library!). And then i got sick of it and threw it away. I suppose i could say i learned a lot while trying to do this sweater.
polished: Last night was the worst. I discarded the sweater I was knitting. I only had about 14 inches completed. I lost around $10 worth of yarn (it's $8 a skein). But I ended up with too many stitches by the time I reached the armholes, and the mohair was tangling, making frogging (ripping out rows) difficult. The yarn broke often. I didn't even swear, which is unusual for me. I just gloomily ripped and listened to season two of Sex and the City (thanks to the library!). Eventually, I got fed up and threw it away. I suppose I learned a lot while attempting to make this sweater.

original: Last night in class, we were discussing that week’s assigned reading, urllink getting back into place: toward a renewed study of the place-world, by edward s. Casey . The first chapter deals with “implacement” and the second, “displacement.” in the first chapter, casey makes the distinction that our contemporary world and culture revolves around time as the situating force: we are running out of time, we have saved time, we are just in time. He is trying to make the case that using place as the center of culture gives a more grounded community. (that is a very rough summation, a disclaimer just in case my professor or any other classmate happens to read this post.) so far, this book is the first reading that has grabbed me by the proverbial shoulders.
polished: Last night in class, we discussed that week's assigned reading, "Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World" by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter deals with “implacement,” while the second focuses on “displacement.” In the first chapter, Casey highlights that our contemporary world revolves around time as the central force: we feel we are running out of time, saving time, and being just in time. He argues that centering culture around place fosters a more grounded community. (This is a very rough summary—just a disclaimer in case my professor or classmates read this post.) So far, this book is the first reading to truly captivate me.

original: Whatever it is they put into freeze pops to make them those colours, there should be some sort of warning: may make your life a bit bizarre. And whilst giggling is good, one wonders if we would have found ourselves up that fire escape drinking beer in the fierce wind had we not been eating them earlier. Finding ourselves in a doorway to a bar sadly closed for business, we stopped to examine an office-supplies catalogue that had arrived in the post. Lucky we did. Who could possibly have guessed that within these pages were the special offers of a lifetime? not i, for certain. I list but a few: buy 36 permanent marker pens, get a stunt kite. Buy 30 lever arch files, get a barbecue.
polished: Whatever they put into freeze pops to achieve those vibrant colors should come with a warning: may cause unexpected adventures. And although laughing is healthy, it makes one wonder if we would have found ourselves climbing that fire escape to drink beer in the strong wind had we not indulged earlier. As we stood in a doorway of a bar sadly closed for business, we paused to sift through an office-supplies catalog that had arrived by mail. Fortunately, we did. Who would have imagined that within these pages were the deals of a lifetime? Certainly not I. Here are just a few: buy 36 permanent marker pens, receive a stunt kite; buy 30 lever arch files, receive a barbecue.

original: Currently listening to: the little drummer boy by stevan pasero ...and now my post... Senate republicans okay, hands up - who watched the 39-hour judicial nominations wankathon last week? i know i didn't. Well, okay - i did tune in once or twice. The entire colossal waste of time was perpetrated by republicans who, pissed off that democrats wouldn't roll over and nominate four of bush's nutjob justices, were trying to score political points by holding a multi-day cry-fest. Never mind the fact that the democrats have already approved 168 of bush's judicial nominees - nooo, that's not good enough for the power-mad republicans who are for some reason laboring under the misapprehension they have a huge mandate for this kind of nonsense.
polished: Currently listening to: "The Little Drummer Boy" by Stevan Pasero. And now my post... Senate Republicans, hands up—who watched the 39-hour judicial nominations marathon last week? I know I didn't. Well, okay—I did tune in once or twice. The entire colossal waste of time was orchestrated by Republicans, annoyed that Democrats wouldn't nominate four of Bush's controversial justices, who were trying to score political points by holding a multi-day event. Never mind the fact that Democrats have already approved 168 of Bush's judicial nominees—that's not good enough for the Republicans who seem to believe they have a huge mandate for this kind of behavior.

original: This was a good weekend. I did a lot of god's green leaf, after a long time, i listened to a lot of nevermore (something i should have started doing much earlier) and read a lot. I finished three books over the weekend - bruce sterling's heavy weather, larry niven's world of ptavvs and octavia butler's parable of the sower. Heavy weather was a good cyberpunk romp through a near-future usa, devastated by global warming and general anarchy. While it was clever, well-paced and altogether very convincing, i must confess that i failed to come away with any really significant sensations about the story or the characters. Not that both aren't well constructed and vividly etched - it's a good book, but not a great one, i guess.
polished: This was a good weekend. I enjoyed nature, listened to a lot of Nevermore (something I should have started doing much earlier), and read extensively. I finished three books: Bruce Sterling's "Heavy Weather," Larry Niven's "World of Ptavvs," and Octavia Butler's "Parable of the Sower." "Heavy Weather" was a good cyberpunk romp through a near-future USA, devastated by global warming and general anarchy. While it was clever, well-paced, and altogether convincing, I must confess that I failed to come away with any really significant impressions about the story or the characters. Not that both aren't well constructed and vividly etched—it's a good book, but not a great one, I guess.

original: Coz' this is the aftermath the first week back from practicum was a struggle but it is only in the second week that the smoke has really started to clear. Post-practicum trauma was a hidden epidemic that is only now coming to light. I was stricken but with the eventual meeting with the course co-ordinator allowed me to release my burden and by doing so i have prevented another person being stuck with such a pedagogically deficit practicum school. Yesterday (monday) i bumped into another agrieved classmate who was quite determined to go to the student who was due to go to her school in the next practicum and tell him how terrible it will be. I calmed her down and said that we should go to the administrator first.
polished: After the first week back from practicum, overcoming the challenges was tough, but only in the second week has the fog truly begun to clear. Post-practicum trauma was an overlooked issue now gaining attention. I was affected, but meeting with the course coordinator allowed me to unburden myself, thus preventing another individual from being placed in a pedagogically deficient practicum school. Yesterday (Monday), I encountered a fellow classmate who was determined to warn the student assigned to her former school about its flaws. I calmed her down, suggesting that we approach the administrator first to address the concerns.

original: Well, things are incredibly busy here at times...but there's always time for supposed stress relieving activities. I've found that i really suck at 8-ball and ping pong! rick(the canuck) beats my ass on a regular basis - we have a ping pong table in the front lobby of our building, always time for a 'quick round'. Last night i participated in an 8-ball tournament over at the hot spot (our recreation tent - complete with popcorn machine, numerous tv's, jukebox, dvd rental, pool table, dart board, and ever present ping pong table). Anyway, i was doing pretty well throughout my one entire game - until i scratched on the eight ball ;( i still had a fairly good time - the most fun was the two dutch soldiers that joined in the tournament.
polished: Things can get incredibly busy here, but there's always time for stress-relieving activities. I've found that I'm not very good at 8-ball and ping pong! Rick, the Canadian, beats me regularly. We have a ping pong table in the front lobby of our building, so there's always time for a quick round. Last night, I participated in an 8-ball tournament at the hot spot, our recreation tent complete with a popcorn machine, numerous TVs, a jukebox, DVD rentals, a pool table, dartboard, and always the ping pong table. I was doing well in my one entire game until I scratched on the eight ball. I still had a good time, especially with the two Dutch soldiers joining the tournament.

original: Fall 1974: i was attempting for what felt like the 13th time to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then nor am i now a math person. I hate math. I am math phobic. You get the picture. So as i struggled to make sense out of algebra the doorbell rang. I put down my book and went to open the door. No one was there. Great. I returned to my studies and just as i was finding a little glimmer of understanding buried in my sub conscious the doorbell rang again. Bam, just like that my breakthrough disappeared. I went to the door and once again no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs, an uninvited practical joker.
polished: In the fall of 1974, I was attempting, for what felt like the 13th time, to navigate the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I wasn’t then, nor am I now, a math person. Math has always been a challenge for me. You get the picture. As I struggled to make sense of algebra, the doorbell rang. I put down my book and opened the door; no one was there. Frustrated, I returned to my studies, just as a little glimmer of understanding emerged. The doorbell rang again, disrupting my breakthrough. Once more, no one was there—a perfect prank for a struggling math student.

original: This past week has been nothing short of exhausting. I spent tuesday-thursday finishing the move to my new classroom. The new room is bigger and closer to my grade level team, these are the things i need to consider as i spend hours upon hours preparing my room for this year. Had i known i was going to move prior to the end of my school year, i would have discarded much of the books and supplies i no longer use. Unfortunately, it all came with me. So this week was spent moving, unpacking, and purging profusely. I have to thank my teammate jill for helping with all of this. You see, she was still teaching this month, in my old room. So she and her lovely students moved almost my entire room for me!
polished: This past week has been nothing short of exhausting. I spent Tuesday to Thursday finishing the move to my new classroom. The new room is bigger and closer to my grade-level team. These are important considerations as I spend hours preparing my room for this year. Had I known I was going to move prior to the end of the school year, I would have discarded many books and supplies I no longer use. Unfortunately, it all came with me. So, this week was spent moving, unpacking, and purging extensively. I have to thank my teammate Jill for helping with everything. She was still teaching this month, in my old room. She and her wonderful students moved almost my entire room for me!

original: You can't help it, you can't evade it: a piece of you will always live in me. Even if i never carried you child, even if i was never married to you, even if i was never an official pair to you ... I loved you immensely, and to this day the feeling carries an echo through my heart. Forever will i always be reminded of the very few nights we spent together, hearts and limbs entwined in a soul-embrace, drenched in the salty darkness of an evening by the beach ... Or a kiss under the rain. Whenever i get the feeling of a dark glass puncturing my heart, you will be there. That piece of you... Bleeding the eternal love that once lived in me ... And still remains. .. For heri
polished: You can't help it, you can't evade it: a piece of you will always live in me. Even if I never carried your child, even if I was never married to you, even if I was never an official pair with you, I loved you immensely, and to this day, the feeling echoes through my heart. I will forever be reminded of those few nights we spent together, hearts and limbs entwined in a soul-embrace, drenched in the salty darkness of an evening by the beach, or a kiss under the rain. Whenever I feel a dark glass puncturing my heart, you will be there. That piece of you... bleeding the eternal love that once lived in me and still remains.

original: I'm uncomfortable. Investigative reporting seems very wrong to me. Or let me rephrase that, the article i'm doing and it's consequences is not exactly something i'm comfortable with. Perhaps it is because i don't believe in it enough, that i cannot really get the complete feel for it. The angst behind it. The full-out passion towards it to question. I've grown up in a country where you don't ask questions. Really, you just don't. They shoot you for that shit. They put you in jail with all these internal security acts. I am not used to this freedom of speech...not used to questioning out loud. Sure, i am not the easiest person to get along with.

original: We had an outing yesterday with my co-employees at the bank. We went to guintubdan, la carolota. It was the first time for most of us. We trekked for the falls. It was a 30 minute or so walk. We were all catching our breaths. Whew! but we made it. The water was chilly ice. You can feel your body getting numb because of the coldness. We only stayed less than an hour because we headed for the nearby waterfalls. Another 30 minutes of trekking. But the trip was worth it because the falls looked calming and the whole scene is indeed breathtaking. Its like you can hear yourself being one with nature. Soaking myself in the cold water was like communing with mother earth. The cold air and water were enough to make you be lulled to sleep.
polished: Yesterday, my colleagues and I went on an outing to Guintubdan, La Carlota. It was a first-time experience for most of us. We embarked on a 30-minute trek to the falls, leaving us breathless, but we persevered. The water was icy, and you could feel your body going numb from the chill. We stayed for less than an hour before heading to a nearby waterfall—another 30-minute trek. The trip was worth it, as the falls presented a calming and breathtaking scene. It felt as if you could hear yourself becoming one with nature. Soaking in the cold water was like communing with Mother Earth, as the cold air and water lulled us into serenity.

original: Saturday we took connor to firemans park, thinking that the fireman's easter egg hunt was to start at 11am. It turned out it was on the friday. polished: On Saturday, we took Connor to Fireman's Park, thinking the Easter egg hunt would start at 11 a.m., but it had actually been on Friday. Thankfully, I had brought a bag of eggs just in case. Connor had a great time finding eggs in the park. On Sunday morning, he was thrilled to find that the Easter Bunny had visited. There's nothing better than seeing the excitement on your child's face. After the egg hunt, we all attended church. Although the 'Easter Bunny' is fun, we ensure our kids understand the true meaning of the holidays. This was Megan's first Easter, and she looked adorable in her jean dress and stockings.

polished: I know in a previous post I defended parents, almost siding with them, but I've had a change of heart. Parents often assume they know us so well, even thinking they can read our emotions. The observers will come from the osce's office for democratic institutions and human rights. It will be the first time such a team has been present for a u.s. Presidential election. With urllink this dot : a baker's dozen of congressional democrats, among them four new yorkers, has petitioned u.n. Secretary- general kofi annan to dispatch international observers to florida to oversee this year's presidential balloting there. I humbly disagree. polished: Some people are quick to connect this dot: The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe was invited to monitor the election by the State Department. The observers will come from the OSCE's Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights. It will be the first time such a team has been present for a U.S. presidential election. Meanwhile, a group of congressional Democrats, including four New Yorkers, has petitioned U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan to send international observers to Florida for this year's presidential election. I humbly disagree. Based on the available information, the OSCE seems to be coming here to learn from the U.S. election process, not to oversee it, contrary to the original partisan call for U.N. involvement.

She had dishes galore—saucers, teapots, coffee cups, wine goblets, water glasses, seven different types of forks and spoons, dinner plates, salad plates, dessert plates, soup bowls, side bowls. I was overwhelmed! Then, she yelled at me for eating appetizers while the turkey was cooking. I insisted I would eat, trust me! After that, it was off to the hospital with my father.

original: Gop gets scolded on recruitment naturalization ceremonies in jacksonville are to be relocated after complaints that gop activists registered new citizens as republicans. By gary fineout and alfonso chardy the citizenship ceremony in jacksonville seemed to go off as usual, with a crowd of nearly 200 people going home as new americans. Just before the new citizens left the june 29 event, an immigration official directing the swearing-in urged them to stop by a voter registration table -- a not uncommon sight at naturalization ceremonies. But this table was unusual: those handing out forms were republican volunteers -- and the party affiliation box had been checked off ahead of time to make all of the new voters members of the gop. All of it was suspicious to linda cross, who was there to watch her husband, dario cruz, take his citizenship oath.
polished: GOP gets reprimanded as Jacksonville naturalization ceremonies are relocated after complaints that GOP activists registered new citizens as Republicans. By Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy. The citizenship ceremony in Jacksonville proceeded as expected, with nearly 200 attendees becoming new Americans. Just before the new citizens departed the June 29 event, an immigration official overseeing the swearing-in encouraged them to visit a voter registration table—a common feature at naturalization ceremonies. However, this table was unusual: Republican volunteers were distributing forms, with the party affiliation box pre-checked to register all new voters as GOP members. This raised suspicion for Linda Cross, who was present to witness her husband, Dario Cruz, take his citizenship oath.

original: I have always prided myself in making anyone that frequents casa pescatore as comforable as possible. I want them to make sure they feel at home as they will feel in their prospective residence. Yesterday- i hope i succeeded. The masses all congregated on perry ave with what many consider ' extreme prejudice'. 4:30pm was the time my best friend eric and his son nunu came over with a huge pan of baked ziti. The tables were set and i had all the food that i cooked and the bells were ringing crazy. Before i could blink - my best friend from florida walked through the door and that made me smile. I missed that motherfucker so much. The bonus was him bringing his wife along. She is expecting and this is the closest i could get to being an uncle. I spoiled that girl with tray after tray of food and tiramisu.
polished: I have always prided myself on making anyone who frequents Casa Pescatore feel as comfortable as possible. I want them to feel at home, just as they would in their own prospective residence. Yesterday, I hope I succeeded. The masses gathered on Perry Ave, with what many consider 'extreme prejudice.' At 4:30 PM, my best friend Eric and his son Nunu came over with a large pan of baked ziti. The tables were set, the food I had prepared was ready, and the bells were ringing like crazy. Before I could blink, my best friend from Florida walked through the door, and that made me smile. I missed him so much. The bonus was him bringing his wife along, who is expecting, and it's the closest I could get to being an uncle. I spoiled her with tray after tray of food and tiramisu.

original: I liked the idea of that as an offence - maybe that could've been a way out of being burned as a witch. As a non-american blogger i've been a little reluctant to get involved in some of these discussions, particularly the bits about flags, but since i started it (the subject, not the flag-burning) i suppose i'd better say something. Firstly, i think that the idea of having a law against flag-burning is completely nuts. The moment you start according a symbol - any symbol - that kind of automatic reverence and protection, you've taken a small but important step towards totalitarianism. Symbols are kind of fickle - they don't a priori represent anything in themselves; it's what they are perceived as meaning or made to represent that's important.
polished: I liked the idea of that as an offense—perhaps it could have been a way out of being burned as a witch. As a non-American blogger, I've been somewhat hesitant to engage in some of these discussions, especially those involving flags. However, since I initiated it (the topic, not the flag-burning), I suppose it's important to comment. Firstly, I believe the idea of having a law against flag-burning is completely absurd. The moment you start granting a symbol—any symbol—that kind of automatic reverence and protection, you've taken a small yet significant step towards totalitarianism. Symbols are inherently fickle; they don't inherently represent anything. It's what they are perceived to mean or what they are made to represent that's important.

original: Holla so i saw troy tonight with my family...i was not impressed. I'm too tired to go way into specifics, but i do think it had potential. However, i think too much energy was spent on the set (which was magnificent) and not enough on creating a solidifying tone, theme, etc. It retold the story, but it was not particularly gripping, and i don't feel like i gained anything from watching it. The character development was rather weak. Additionally, i thought the score was poor, and was basically a knock-off of the gladiator. The gladiator used the background music of a moaning woman and it worked b/c it backed up and complemented a genuinely gripping narrative.
polished: Hello, I watched "Troy" with my family tonight, but I wasn't impressed. I'm too tired for specifics, but it had potential. However, too much energy went into the magnificent set design, and not enough into creating a cohesive tone and theme. It retold the story but wasn't particularly gripping, and I didn't feel like I gained anything from it. The character development was rather weak. Additionally, I thought the score was poor and essentially a knock-off of "Gladiator." In "Gladiator," the background music of a moaning woman worked well because it complemented a genuinely gripping narrative.

polished: Urllink PulpFiction 1.0, from the creators at Freshly Squeezed Software, is the latest atom/RDF/RSS reader on the scene. It boasts many appealing native app features. However, it's important to mention that it isn't free, reflecting a recurring 'hot topic' online. Users can explore it with a 15-day trial before deciding to purchase it for $25. Additionally, it offers the capability to import and export OPML, as expected.

Oh how i miss them all. Tomorrow is the start of a new term. How did the holidays fly by so quickly?
polished: Today, I miss my sister terribly—it feels strange not to have her around, irritating me (just joking...). Even though she was here for only a week, she made her presence felt, and I mean that in a good way. Creating the scrapbook for our trip to Tasmania brings back fond memories of last week. Maybe it's the thought of not seeing her for quite a while, with her going to Bristol in September/October. She represented a deeper connection to my family back home. Oh, how I miss them all. Tomorrow marks the start of a new term. How did the holidays fly by so quickly?

original: Ever have one of those days when you just don't know what the... What the... Anything? no? well then you should skip the rest of this because it won't make any sense to you. To those of you choosing to continue on i offer the following observation. ' sometimes i wish i'd been given the manual .' manuals, if done correctly at least, let you know: what things are for, what they can do, how they do the things they do, what happens if you push button x or y, what to do if things aren't doing what they're supposed to the phone number and email address of the omniscient guru who can solve every problem very useful information. Unfortunately i didn't get a manual with me.
polished: Ever had one of those days when you just can't figure anything out? No? Then you should probably skip the rest of this, as it might not make sense to you. For those of you continuing, I offer this observation: "Sometimes I wish I'd been given the manual." Manuals, when well-written, provide valuable insights: what things are for, what they can do, how they operate, what happens if you press certain buttons, and what to do when things aren't working correctly. They even have the contact information of the all-knowing guru who can solve every problem. Unfortunately, I didn't receive a manual with me.

original: And there's nothing wrong with pcs -- if i were a full-bore gamer with time to do such a thing, i'd certainly have a pc system for the wealth of available games. Though except for a few unique products, that huge wall of games at compusa starts getting repetetive after a while -- at first i'm envious, then i start noticing that it's really just a lot of different flavors of the same soda...first-person shooters, mystery games, strategy games, simulations. There are so many variations of age of empires it becomes comical. Aoe -- with orcs! aoe -- with spaceships! aoe -- with fuzzy wombats! it's like the endless movie trailers that begin with the line: 'in a world...'
polished: There's nothing wrong with PCs. If I were an avid gamer with time, I'd certainly own a PC for its vast selection of games. However, aside from a few unique titles, the extensive game selection at stores like CompUSA becomes repetitive. Initially, I feel envious, but soon realize it's just many variations of the same genres: first-person shooters, mystery games, strategy games, simulations. The numerous versions of Age of Empires, for example, become amusing: AoE with orcs, AoE with spaceships, AoE with fuzzy wombats! It's reminiscent of endless movie trailers that all start with the cliché: "In a world...

original: Jdasovic.nsf monday, december 11, 2000 to: all px market participants from: john yurkanin chief operating officer re: loss of continuity in px day ahead auction due to iso rule changes the emergency tariff filing by the california iso last friday has had a negative effect on the px day ahead auction market. The mixture of soft and hard caps results in a complete disconnect and unacceptable risk to all of our participants and will probably not provide the iso with its sought after reduction in real time energy sales and procurement. The overall effect will be that supply will still defer to the higher realized price opportunity the iso offers. The px is petitioning terry winter of the iso to immediately allow for adjustment bids on any submitted schedule at any price relevant.
polished:
Jdasovic.nsf  
Monday, December 11, 2000  

To: All PX Market Participants  
From: John Yurkanin, Chief Operating Officer  
Re: Loss of Continuity in PX Day-Ahead Auction Due to ISO Rule Changes  

The emergency tariff filing by the California ISO last Friday has adversely affected the PX day-ahead auction market. The combination of soft and hard caps creates a disconnect and poses unacceptable risks to all participants and likely will not achieve the ISO's goal of reducing real-time energy sales and procurement. As a result, suppliers will continue to defer to the higher realized price opportunities offered by the ISO. The PX is petitioning Terry Winter of the ISO to promptly allow for adjustment bids on any submitted schedule at any price level.

original: Mark guzman 6-28-02.nsf just wanted to make sure you saw this from les rawson concerning grays harbor and willamette. -bill beginning immediately enron has purchased control area reserves service from bpa. The allows services to sell unit contingent energy as hourly firm since bpa is suppling reserves for up to 60 minutes. If grays harbor paper notifies rt of a unit derate or outage rt should notify bpa dispatch immediately and make the reduction in the schedule during the next ramp. For example should grays unit trip as 1333 rt would notify bpa and the sink that across the top of the hour for 1400 the schedule would be taken to zero for he 1400. The bottom line is that 60 minutes is the maximum time bpa will carry the schedule.
polished:
Subject: Important Update on Control Area Reserves Service

Hello,

I wanted to ensure you saw this message from Les Rawson regarding Grays Harbor and Willamette.

Please take note: Effective immediately, Enron has acquired control area reserves service from BPA. This acquisition enables the sale of unit contingent energy as hourly firm energy, as BPA provides reserves for up to 60 minutes.

In the event that Grays Harbor Paper experiences a unit derate or outage, RT should promptly notify BPA dispatch and adjust the schedule accordingly. For example, if the Grays unit trips at 13:33, RT is to inform BPA immediately. The schedule should then be reduced to zero by the top of the hour at 14:00.

Please remember that 60 minutes is the maximum time BPA can support the schedule.

In the cross-default language that want to add language that basically says that even if a cross-default occurs, unless the non-defaulting determines in good faith that performance by the defaulting party of its obligations under the master is "endangered", then no cross default is triggered. 2. In credit event upon merger we had commented that instaed of the "materially weaker" standard we wanted to specify that it meant being rated below bbb- by s&p. Do you feel strongly about this?

original: Khyatt (non-privileged).pst el paso tests market for mainline expansion el paso natural gas apparently got the message when its last open season for 1.2 bcf/d of firm transportation capacity attracted bids for 14.4 bcf/d. The pipeline has announced an open season to test market interest in a mainline expansion and to satisfy regulatory concerns that something needs to be done to relieve the apparent capacity constraint at the california border. El paso has been under significant pressure from regulators and shippers to expand because of enormous demand and skyrocketing prices in california. In a jan. 3 letter to the pipeline, daniel m. Adamson, director of ferc's office of energy projects, urged el paso to consider modifying its line 2000 project to "assist the difficult situation" now facing the california gas market.
polished:
Khyatt (non-privileged).pst - El Paso Tests Market for Mainline Expansion

El Paso Natural Gas responded to high interest when its last open season for 1.2 bcf/d of firm transportation capacity received bids for 14.4 bcf/d. The pipeline has announced an open season to gauge market interest in a mainline expansion, addressing regulatory concerns about the capacity constraints at the California border. El Paso faces significant pressure from regulators and shippers to expand due to enormous demand and skyrocketing prices in California. In a January 3 letter to the pipeline, Daniel M. Adamson, director of FERC's Office of Energy Projects, urged El Paso to consider modifying its Line 2000 project to "assist the difficult situation" now facing the California gas market.

original: Sscott5.nsf ahimsa (uh-him-sah) noun the principle of noninjury to living beings. [sanskrit ahimsa : a-, not + himsa, injury (from himsati, he injures).] "as my conception of ahimsa went on maturing, i became more vigilant about my thought and speech. The lines in the anthem: scatter her enemies and make them fall; confound their policies, frustrate their knavish tricks particularly jarred upon my sentiments of ahimsa." m.k. Gandhi, the story of my experiments with truth, 1927. Today is october 2, the day mohandas karamchand gandhi was born in the year 1869. A man born some two centuries ago may appear irrelevant to our age, but in reality his life and message are still applicable to our lives today.

Gandhi, The Story of My Experiments with Truth, 1927. Today is October 2, the day Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi was born in 1869. A man born so long ago may seem irrelevant, but his life and message are still applicable to our times.

original: Mgrigsb.nsf ? over the weekend, gov. Davis and senate polance made an informal agreement whereby senate polance has agreed to sponsor the socal mou bill. Polanco is a democrat and is currently suffering through a personal scandal and as a result, it is reported that his political career is essential dead. Polance is planning to run for mayor of los angeles rather than run for another senate term. ? the bill is expected to be introduced in the new extraordinary session, beginning today or tomorrow. The bill would first go to the senate energy committee. Sen. Bowen, the chair of the committee, strongly opposes the mou, so the bill is expected to remain in committee hearings for some time. The longer the bill is involved in committee politics and changes are made, the likelihood of a socal bankruptcy increases.
polished: Over the weekend, Governor Davis and Senator Polanco made an informal agreement whereby Polanco agreed to sponsor the Southern California MOU bill. Polanco, a Democrat, is currently embroiled in a personal scandal, leading to reports that his political career may be over. Instead of seeking another Senate term, he is considering a run for mayor of Los Angeles. The bill is expected to be introduced in the new extraordinary session, starting today or tomorrow. Initially, it will be reviewed by the Senate Energy Committee. Senator Bowen, the committee chair, strongly opposes the MOU, so the bill is anticipated to remain in committee hearings for a while. Prolonged committee involvement and modifications could increase the likelihood of Southern California facing bankruptcy.

original: Sshackle.nsf notice no. 00-338 october 3, 2000 memorandum to: all nymex and comex members from: neal l. Wolkoff, executive vice president date: october 3, 2000 re: notice of cftc approval of new nymex rule 6.40c: ("average price calculations by futures commission merchants") please be advised that the cftc has approved new nymex rule 6.40c ("average price calculations by futures commission merchants"), which is attached and is now in effect. New nymex rule 6.40c, which is consistent with a recent cftc "advisory," permits fcms, under certain conditions specified in the rule, to use their own internal, proprietary systems to generate average price ("ap") calculations when multiple prices are received on an order or series of orders.
polished:
Subject: CFTC Approval of NYMEX Rule 6.40C  
Date: October 3, 2000  
From: Neal L. Wolkoff, Executive Vice President  

To All NYMEX and COMEX Members,

Please be informed that the CFTC has approved new NYMEX Rule 6.40C, titled "Average Price Calculations by Futures Commission Merchants." This rule, which is now effective, is consistent with a recent CFTC advisory. It permits Futures Commission Merchants (FCMs) to use their own internal, proprietary systems to generate average price calculations when multiple prices are received on an order or series of orders, under certain conditions specified in the rule. The approved rule is attached for your reference.

original: Sshackle.nsf as of this week enrononline has just started offering us/canadian dollar swaps online. As part of my review in determining whether a counterparty can transact these products online i look at the financial trading agreement database to see if there are any restrictions indicated, check the master swap agreement, and i am also looking at any board resolutions we might have received when we got the master agreement executed. What i am finding is that in the old days when we asked for resolutions evidencing the authority to enter into the master agreement/derivative transactions frequently the resolutions do not allow the counterparies to enter into currency transactions. Since transacting these currency transactions with our energy customers is a new area of business for us i just wanted us all to be mindful to check these old resolutions and not to rely solely on the "restrictions" contained in lotus notes.
polished: As of this week, EnronOnline has started offering US/Canadian dollar swaps online. When reviewing whether a counterparty can conduct transactions for these products online, I examine the Financial Trading Agreement database to identify any restrictions, check the master swap agreement, and review any board resolutions we obtained when executing the master agreement. Historically, when we requested resolutions demonstrating the authority to enter into the master agreement or derivative transactions, these resolutions often did not permit the counterparts to engage in currency transactions. Since engaging in currency transactions with our energy customers is a new business area for us, I wanted to remind everyone to carefully review these older resolutions and not rely solely on the "restrictions" noted in Lotus Notes.

original: Dhyvl.nsf dave, i will be glad to generate the form of transaction agreement; however, i have a number of questions. 1. Relationship of delivery point and the use of interruptible transport on northwest pipeline. Is the transport upstream or downstream of the delivery point? if downstream, why isn't it being contracted for by eweb. 2. What volume is being sold each day. You use the term dcq and you also talk about a 20% tolerance above or below the estimated quantity. Normally their would be no tolerance with a dcq transaction. 3. Is this envisioned to be a requirements transaction. Is the price the same for volumes in excess of the estimated quantity up to an additional 20%.
polished: Dhyvl.nsf Dave, I will be glad to generate the transaction agreement form; however, I have several questions. 1. What is the relationship between the delivery point and the use of interruptible transport on the Northwest Pipeline? Is the transport upstream or downstream of the delivery point? If downstream, why isn't it being contracted for by EWEB? 2. What volume is being sold each day? You mention DCQ and discuss a 20% tolerance above or below the estimated quantity. Normally, there would be no tolerance with a DCQ transaction. 3. Is this intended to be a requirements transaction? Is the price the same for volumes exceeding the estimated quantity by up to an additional 20%?

original: Jdasovic.nsf the spreadsheet below gives the implicit commodity based on the effective date of four different rates for the same rate schedule (schedule dr). The rate schedule effective august 2000 through september 2000 yields a much larger commodity charge because sdg&e customers will receive a lump sum reimbursement from sdg&e over those two months. Sdg&e customers will expect lower electric bills. Assuming that the lump sum reimbursement is not included in the implicit energy component, the average for june 2000 through january 2001 is 6.2 cts and the implicit commodity average from february 2001 through december 2001 is 7.3 cts. The average implicit commodity from june 2000 through december 2001 is 6.9 cts for deliveries starting september 1, 2000, the average would still be 6.9 cts.
polished: The spreadsheet below presents the implicit commodity based on the effective dates of four distinct rates within the same rate schedule (Schedule DR). The rate schedule effective from August 2000 through September 2000 results in a significantly higher commodity charge because SDG&E customers receive a lump sum reimbursement from SDG&E during those months. Consequently, SDG&E customers can expect lower electric bills. Assuming this reimbursement is excluded from the implicit energy component, the average for June 2000 through January 2001 is 6.2 cents, and the implicit commodity average from February 2001 through December 2001 is 7.3 cents. The overall average implicit commodity from June 2000 through December 2001 is 6.9 cents. Deliveries starting September 1, 2000, would maintain this 6.9 cents average.

original: Tdonoho (non-privileged).pst this has been a tough couple of weeks. I hope that these daily communications on new developments are helping you understand what's happening with our company. Here's a rundown of events from last week: we executed a commitment letter with jpmorgan and salomon smith barney that will provide us with additional secured credit lines worth $1 billion. Our northern natural gas company and transwestern pipeline company will support these assets. We now have received a total of $4 billion in credit lines, which we will use to pay off short-term commercial debt and maintain liquidity. Our board of directors elected a new member to the board - william powers, jr., the dean of the university of texas school of law in austin, texas.
polished: This has been a challenging couple of weeks. I hope these daily updates on new developments are helping you understand what's happening with our company. Here's a summary of last week's events: We executed a commitment letter with JPMorgan and Salomon Smith Barney to provide us with additional secured credit lines worth $1 billion. Our Northern Natural Gas Company and Transwestern Pipeline Company will support these assets. We have now received a total of $4 billion in credit lines, which we will use to pay off short-term commercial debt and maintain liquidity. Our board of directors elected a new member - William Powers, Jr., the dean of the University of Texas School of Law in Austin, Texas.

original: Skean.nsf i am attaching the ferc order and staff recommendations. The order provides for $69 million in "potential" refunds (either pay up or provide cost justification). Enron was not named as one of the 13 overcharging parties, but pge was ($3.18 million). It's not over yet, though. The order deals only with jan 01 and promises further orders regarding dec 00 and benchmark prices through april 01. The prices used to determine refunds were fairly high ($273/mwh based on gas prices, emissions costs and an assumed heat rate of over 16000). With respect to sales to california, we have concluded at least one short term sale and have talked with cal dept of water resources about longer term deals, but we were still struggling with credit issues, last i heard.
polished: I am attaching the FERC order and staff recommendations. The order provides for $69 million in "potential" refunds, requiring either payment or cost justification. Enron was not named as one of the 13 overcharging parties, but PGE was ($3.18 million). It's not over yet, though. The order addresses only January 2001 and anticipates further orders concerning December 2000 and benchmark prices through April 2001. The prices used to determine refunds were quite high ($273/MWh, based on gas prices, emissions costs, and an assumed heat rate of over 16,000). Regarding sales to California, we have completed at least one short-term sale and have discussed longer-term deals with the California Department of Water Resources, but we were still encountering credit issues, last I heard.

original: It puts the ball in the net or it gets the hose again. Absolutely amazing, have nothing negative to say about this game as it's exceeded my expectations and will probably exeed yours too. Fluid movement, bug/crash free, lots of story/content to put you through, options for each and every day such as multiple practices, events (sponsorships) and even games. This review is purely based on playing mycareer, and so far it's 10/10. Facescan worked really well for me (used it two times, first one made me have a downsyndrome forehead though..). Keep in mind, using the mynba2k17 app will allow for you to facescan for free and allow you to earn daily vc. #sellout
polished: It's a fantastic experience—absolutely amazing. I have nothing negative to say about this game as it has exceeded my expectations and will likely exceed yours too. The movement is fluid, it’s free of bugs and crashes, and there’s an abundance of story and content to engage with. You have daily options like multiple practices, events (sponsorships), and even games. This review is purely based on playing MyCareer, and so far, it's a 10/10. FaceScan worked really well for me. Keep in mind, using the MyNBA2K17 app allows you to FaceScan for free and earn daily VC. #sellout

original: Magic fans beware... Wizards is afraid to make a decent digital game. At its core magic the gathering is a social game. A game to enjoy with your friends (or frenemies) laughing, talking smack, and dropping game winning bombs. Wizards of the coast seems to have forgotten this. If you choose to play with friends you cant earn gold, and gold is important. Gold is so important that they have implemented a daily cap, understandable considering gold unlocks everything in game. But get ready for a long and boring 1v1 grind against the computer or random oponents, whom you can't even speak to. If you choose to play for free, it will take you roughly 4 hours a day for upwards of a month, by yourself, to unlock the cards.
polished: Magic fans beware... Wizards seems hesitant to create a decent digital game. At its core, Magic: The Gathering is a social game—a game to enjoy with friends or frenemies, sharing laughs, talking smack, and achieving game-winning moves. Wizards of the Coast appears to have forgotten this. If you choose to play with friends, you can't earn gold, which is crucial. Gold is so important that they've implemented a daily cap, understandable since it unlocks everything in the game. Instead, prepare for a long and dull 1v1 grind against the computer or random opponents, whom you can't even communicate with. If you choose to play for free, expect to spend roughly 4 hours a day, for at least a month, to unlock the cards.

original: Being the 3rd installment in the trilogy i'll get the bad stuff out of the way first. I quite hate pre-quals as it's technically going backwards in a story and not forwards (this is an issue for every pre-qual). Granted it offers more storywise. The combat feels sloppy and doesn't feel as sharp as arkham city managed to make it. As of writing this recommendation (26/10/2013) there is a game breaking bug that stops a side mission from ever being completed (main story not effected). Some gadgets are put at a rediculous hotkey that makes your hand have to travel the whole keyboard to get to it. It might sound like nothing, but while in combat it could potentially break your combo.
polished: As the third installment in the trilogy, I'll address the drawbacks first. I quite dislike prequels because they technically go backward in the story rather than forward, which is an issue for every prequel. However, they do offer more story development. The combat feels sloppy and lacks the sharpness that Arkham City achieved. As of writing this recommendation (26/10/2013), there is a game-breaking bug that prevents the completion of a side mission (the main story is not affected). Some gadgets are assigned to an inconvenient hotkey, requiring your hand to travel across the keyboard. It might seem minor, but during combat, it could potentially disrupt your combo.

original: They basically fixed shadow warrior (2013) i.e. The bossfights are awesome, weapons feel very nice (maybe not as good as d44m's ones, but still solid), enemies aren't too spongy (if you're not too much of a retard with handling elemental and upgrade stuff). The upgrade system is really balanced and once you get around it, it's not too tedious. The elemental stuff and limited ammo softly forces you to use different weapons. Lots of cool unique (being the important word here while comparing sw2 to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ borderlands' formula of 'rng' weapons) weapons that stay viable through most of the game. The music is great, especially the main theme and of course stan bush's stuff.
polished: Shadow Warrior (2013) has been significantly improved. The boss fights are amazing, and the weapons feel impressive—perhaps not quite at the level of Doom 2016’s, but still robust. Enemies aren't overly tough if you manage elemental and upgrade features wisely. The upgrade system is well-balanced and becomes less tedious once you understand it. Elemental features and limited ammo encourage you to use different weapons. There are many unique, interesting weapons—unlike the procedurally generated ones in Borderlands—that remain useful throughout most of the game. The music is fantastic, particularly the main theme and Stan Bush’s contributions.

original: So many things was made wrong. I even dont know how to start this review. This all is refered to mycareer. My player is an outside scorer, pg, 1.71m, has maxed stats and got already all necessary perks. Ok, and now tell me, why the shooting skill depends to a person's hight? why a person who has 1.74m can not became so good in shooting as a person with 1.71m? i'm 1.87m in rl, made my first player with this hight and noticed then i can not reach a higher skill than 89. Why? thats a pure discrimination! and why the game does not tell me that before i create a char and not even then when i reach the skill limit after weeks of playing?!?
polished: So many things were done wrong. I'm not even sure where to start this review. This all pertains to MyCareer. My player is an outside scorer, PG, 1.71m tall, with maxed stats and all necessary perks. Now, tell me, why does shooting skill depend on a person's height? Why can't someone who is 1.74m be as good at shooting as someone who is 1.71m? In real life, I'm 1.87m. I made my first player with this height and noticed I can't reach a skill higher than 89. Why? That's pure discrimination! And why doesn't the game inform me of this before I create a character or even when I reach the skill limit after weeks of playing?!

original: I think this assassin's creed nailed the mechanics down on all fronts (ship battles, sailing, hunting (fish), parkour, etc). I felt much more attached to this character as well. The story starts out extremely rough but does get much much better as you play (i think this is with every ac game personally). Edward was quite the interesting character and so was all the side characters. I felt like all the collectables actually meant something in this ac game that i never got from any of the previous ones and maybe its because i felt like they had a bigger purpose in the game. They def were not required but they were fun to get and you got rewarded in a very balanced way.
polished: In this installment of Assassin's Creed, the game truly excels in mechanics across all aspects, including ship battles, sailing, hunting, parkour, and more. I found myself more connected to the main character. Initially, the story begins roughly but improves significantly as the game progresses—something I've noticed with every AC game. Edward is a fascinating character, as are the side characters. The collectibles in this game felt meaningful, a sentiment I didn’t experience with previous entries. Perhaps it's because they seemed to have a more significant purpose in this game. While not required, they were fun to obtain, offering balanced rewards.

original: While i personally cannot recommend this game, it wasn't absolutely terrible. The gunplay is alright, so long as you have the money to purchase gun parts, which would be my main complaint with this game: it's pay-to-win. If i could get past that, the game would be enjoyable, as the hardsuit is fun to use and hrv is an excellent idea. I'd take this game over any call of duty title any day, but its pay-to-win microtransanction format is off-putting for me. If you are alright with this model, then by all means, have fun. But if you're like me and dislike pay-to-win games, just let this one slide; it's not our cup of tea.
polished: While I personally cannot recommend this game, it wasn't absolutely terrible. The gunplay is decent, provided you have the funds to purchase gun parts. This leads to my main complaint: it's pay-to-win. If I could overlook that, the game would be enjoyable. The hardsuit is fun to use, and HRV is an excellent concept. I'd choose this game over any Call of Duty title, but its pay-to-win microtransaction model is discouraging. If you don't mind this approach, then enjoy it. However, if you're like me and oppose pay-to-win schemes, let this one go; it's not our cup of tea.

original: While not perfect, this game has been greatly enjoyable. The save system and possibility of sudden death leads to some frustration. I'm on my first playthrough and i lost my main character around hour 10 of 20ish. Would have really liked a save to reload at that point. I've since picked up a 3rd party mod/save tool to avoid catastrophic failures. Plus the aiming reticule is on the small side and zoom is underpowered. With all that said, its been a blast. I'm not normally a zombie fan, but the combination of strategy, missions, first person shooter/beat em up is great. I've been playing it as often as i can get away... Just one more mission, just one more supply run - or i'm running away and want to get safe before shutting the game down.
polished: Although not flawless, this game has been highly enjoyable. The save system and the possibility of sudden death can be frustrating. During my first playthrough, I lost my main character around hour 10 out of approximately 20. I would have appreciated a save option to reload at that point. I've since used a third-party mod/save tool to prevent catastrophic failures. Additionally, the aiming reticle is small and the zoom is underpowered. Despite these issues, the game has been a blast. I'm not usually a zombie fan, but the blend of strategy, missions, and first-person shooter/beat-em-up elements is fantastic. I play it as often as possible, always telling myself—just one more mission, one more supply run—or escaping to safety before shutting the game down.

original: An absolute great stragtegy game! having played every single other wargame (european escalation, and alb), i have to say this one fits well. The number of units are great. Not sure exactly how many units there are, but there's a crap ton!!! graphics are just beautiful, sounds are great, and the gameplay overall is epic. The ingame chat box at the main menu is very entertaining as well, no i am not kidding. However, if anyone thinking this game is 'easy', or if you are new to the strategy genre, it could take you quite some time to get it nailed down. Do not get upset, you will lose a lot of units. Just make sure you plan ahead, always have anti-air, and anti-tank.
polished: An absolutely great strategy game! Having played every single other wargame (European Escalation, and ALB), I have to say this one fits well. The number of units is impressive. Not sure exactly how many, but there’s a ton! The graphics are beautiful, the sounds are great, and the overall gameplay is epic. The in-game chat box at the main menu is very entertaining, no kidding. However, if you're new to the strategy genre, it could take time to master. Don’t get discouraged; you will lose units. Just plan ahead, and always have anti-air and anti-tank.

original: I was negatively biased towards this game before i played it. Wasn't even sure about buying. I dunno, the whole portal gun and portals thing seemed weird to me even though i like science fiction. Boy was i wrong. The jokes and voice acting in this game is phenomenal. Just amazing. It's not cheesy (ok it's sometimes cheesy). And different story characters have all their own sense of humour. Those different characters do really have different personalities. And the level design; it's just rad. Btw i never played the first portal game. One of these days, i'm planning to if i can spare the time. I would never have played it if i hadn't played the sequel.
polished: I was initially skeptical about this game before I played it. I wasn't even sure about buying it. The whole portal gun and portal concept seemed odd to me, even though I enjoy science fiction. Boy, was I wrong. The jokes and voice acting in this game are phenomenal. Simply amazing. It's not cheesy (well, occasionally), and each character has their own unique sense of humor and personality. The level design is superb. By the way, I never played the first Portal game. One of these days, I'm planning to, if I can spare the time. I would never have considered it if I hadn't played the sequel.

original: Ok lets start on the pros(+) and cons(-) then my thoughts on this game. +some of the best charecters +good story +lods of content +customisible charecter ( you can be male or female whatever you like) +you can have a relationship with most of your companions(yes fangirls you can have a love intrest) -bad graphics ( i dont think graphics really matter anyway) -weird and akward love scenes -invisible walls -theirs one mission in my opinion was boring but everyone has different tastes -+ um this isnt really bad or good but for those who care your protaginist you made cant talk okay know for my thoughts. I love this game. This game is probubly one of the best rpgs or games in general i have ever played.so if your a rpg fan you proubly already have this game.
polished:
Let's start with the pros (+) and cons (-), followed by my thoughts on this game. 

Pros: 
+ Some of the best characters 
+ Good story 
+ Loads of content 
+ Customizable character (you can be male or female, whatever you like)
